text: Hi <@UCQB6S222> - although this is viable, it would challenge the simplicity of the original idea behind cross-matching for those who aren't familiar with the process.  We can raise it as an idea but we'd need to put some thought into whether this will lead to an overall better experience for customers.  The initial feeling is that this could cause confusion, outweighing any perceived benefits.

elements.text: - although this is viable, it would challenge the simplicity of the original idea behind cross-matching for those who aren't familiar with the process.  We can raise it as an idea but we'd need to put some thought into whether this will lead to an overall better experience for customers.  The initial feeling is that this could cause confusion, outweighing any perceived benefits.

text:
Thanks Neil - appreciate it. I suppose the other option would just be to allow API customers to turn off cross-matching.
The use case would be as follows - if I wanted to send both a Back Player A @ 1.32 and a Lay Player B @ 4.1, but I wanted to ensure that the Lay Player B order was matched first because it would avoid the loss I would incur from being cross-matched at 1.32.
In theory, allowing customers to turn it off could lead to occasional underrounds on the book - however in practice this is incredibly unlikely because anyone using the API who deliberately requests to turn off cross-matching (when it is on by default) can probably be trusted that they know what they are doing.

In theory, allowing customers to turn it off could lead to occasional underrounds on the book - however in practice this is incredibly unlikely because anyone using the API who deliberately requests to turn off cross-matching (when it is on by default) can probably be trusted that they know what they are doing.

text: Hi <@UFTBRB3F1> - I've raised this request to the Exchange Ops team and will let you know what can be done here.  It would make sense to offer a no-reply email address so that error notifications can be sent directly to our Ops team

text: Great, thanks Neil that sounds like a quick win if it's possible.
